abstract.p: Sheila M Reilly letter, in response to Oct 19, questions use of focus groups in presidential election; says our leaders are elected to lead, and yet they seem increasinly to follow

block.p: Re ''To Some Complaints, Focus Groups Emerge as Stars of the Fall Season'' (news article, Oct. 19):

I am a market research professional with 20 years' experience, the last five spent specializing in qualitative research, a k a focus groups. I will add my voice to those who offer a strong caveat regarding the lack of statistical reliability or projectability of such data. Yet my greater concern is with the increased use of research, particularly focus groups, not to elicit information regarding voters' attitudes and preferences, but so that our leaders may use this information to set policy!
Re ''To Some Complaints, Focus Groups Emerge as Stars of the Fall Season'' (news article, Oct. 19):

I am a market research professional with 20 years' experience, the last five spent specializing in qualitative research, a k a focus groups. I will add my voice to those who offer a strong caveat regarding the lack of statistical reliability or projectability of such data. Yet my greater concern is with the increased use of research, particularly focus groups, not to elicit information regarding voters' attitudes and preferences, but so that our leaders may use this information to set policy!
Our leaders are elected to lead, and yet they seem increasingly to follow.
SHEILA M. REILLY Newport, R.I., Oct. 19, 2000
